journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Effects of remedial actions on small piping reliability

contrib-group.aff: Infra-Res Laboratory, University of Souk Ahras, Souk Ahras, Algeria

author-notes.corresp: Abdelmoumene Guedri, Infra-Res Laboratory, University of Souk Ahras, PO Box 1553, Souk Ahras 41000, Algeria. Email: guedri_moumen@yahoo.fr

abstract.p: This article describes probabilistic calculations that address intergranular stress corrosion cracking of stainless steel piping; a degradation mechanism of major concern to nuclear pressure boundary integrity. The objective is to simulate the cracking of stainless steel piping under intergranular stress corrosion cracking conditions, and to evaluate the structural reliability using remedial actions for intergranular stress corrosion cracking that are limited to benefits of in-service inspections and the induction heating stress improvement process. The results show that an effective in-service inspection requires a suitable combination of flaw detection capability and inspection schedule, and it has been suggested that the residual stresses could be altered to become favorable, thereby improving the reliability piping.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: One of the important degradation mechanisms to be considered for alloyed steels is stress corrosion cracking (SCC). This mechanism causes cracking in the material owing to the combined action of a susceptible material, a tensile stress, and a corrosive environment. In boiler water reactor (BWR) piping, the susceptible material is usually AISI 304 stainless steel in a sensitized condition next to weldments. The susceptibility of this material to intergranular SCC (IGSCC) is owing to chromium carbide precipitation in the grain boundaries, which leaves the regions immediately adjacent to these grain boundaries low in corrosion-resistant chromium.1 The precipitation occurs most commonly under the thermal conditions encountered during welding. The stress is primarily owing to weld shrinkage during fabrication, and the corrosive environment results from coolant oxygen and low impurity levels according to the operating specifications.2

The purpose of this article is to apply probabilistic fracture mechanics (PFM) to analyze the influence of remedial actions on austenitic stainless steels piping structural reliability. PFM provides a technique for estimating the probability of failure of a structure or one of its components when such failures are considered to occur as the result of the sub-critical and catastrophic growth of an initial crack-like defect. Such techniques are inherently capable of treating the influence of non-destructive inspections.3–6 Several articles in the literature7–11 addressed the probabilistic failure analysis of components subjected to IGSCC. Failure probabilities of a piping component subjected to IGSCC, including the effects of residual stresses, were computed by Guedri et al.12–13 using Monte Carlo simulation (MCS) techniques.

IGSCC in the heat-affected zones of stainless steel welds is much more difficult to detect by ultrasonic testing (UT) inspection techniques. The IGSCC tends to be extremely tight, and is often highly branched at the crack tip. It is also difficult to distinguish between UT echo signals from cracks and from the weld root. Thus it is very hard to detect IGSCC, and even more difficult to determine the depth accurately.14 As a result, UT in-service inspection (ISI), conducted in accordance with the minimum requirements of Section XI of the ASME boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, tends to be of little value for this problem.

In this study, remedy actions for IGSCC, which are limited to benefit ISIs and the induction heating stress improvement process, have been proposed. The simulation of stainless steel piping cracking under IGSCC conditions is based on the general methodology recommended in the Piping Reliability Analysis Including Seismic Events (PRAISE) computer program.15 IGSCC is characterized by a single damage parameter that depends on residual stresses, BWR environment conditions, and degree of sensitization. This parameter can be used to evaluate the structural reliability and to identify most effective approaches to improving piping reliability.

sec.title: Piping reliability model
sec.p: The piping reliability model was developed on the basis of PFM concepts. The computational procedure using the MCS for the estimation of leak probability combines various random variables, such as initial crack size distribution, crack detection probability, crack growth relation, and the stress history.

The procedures shown in Figure 1 are applicable to a given location in a structure. The crack size distribution is combined with the non-detection probability to provide the post-inspection distribution. The manner in which the cracks that escape detection grow is then calculated by fracture mechanics techniques. The cumulative probability of failure at any time is simply the probability of having a crack at that time equal to or larger than the critical crack size. Pre-service and ISIs of piping weldments are performed using UT. Prior to its first startup, the primary coolant system of a nuclear reactor undergoes several pre-service inspections designed to locate as-fabricated defects. The welds may be periodically subjected to ISIs. The procedure for modeling ISIs is similar to its treatment in pre-service inspections. The crack size distribution at the time of the first ISI can be calculated. This pre-inspection distribution is combined with the non-detection probability to provide the post-inspection distribution. Fracture mechanics calculations then proceed up to the next ISI, at which time the procedures are again applied. Because of the complexity of the two-dimensional cracks growth fracture mechanics calculations and the complicated bivariate nature of the crack size distribution, calculations of the failure probability are performed numerically. Finally, it is obvious that crack detection capability and inspection time influence the leak probability results because they are the last elements to prevent pipe leak once the crack grows in the simulation.

caption.p: Computational procedure used in estimating leak probability for nuclear power plant piping.

sec.title: Probabilistic SCC model
sec.p: In this section the methodology recommended in PRAISE for modeling IGSCC in stainless steel pipe is presented and all cracks are two-dimensional semi-elliptical interior surface cracks, generally circumferentially oriented, as shown in Figure 2. PRAISE separates the overall time to pipe leak into three steps:15

list-item.p: time to initiate very small cracks;
time spent growing the small cracks at an initiation velocity v1;
time spent growing larger cracks at fracture mechanics velocity v2 to become through-wall cracks.

caption.p: Geometry of the part-through circumferential crack considered.

sec.title: Initiation and growth of cracks
sec.p: The time to crack initiation under static load conditions has been found to be a function of the damage parameter Dσ as presented in equation (1). Therefore, the time to crack initiation tI for a given Dσ is taken to be log-normally distributed. The mean and standard deviation of Log (tI) are given in Harris and Dedhia15 by
The damage parameter Dσ represents the effects of loading, environment, and material variables on IGSCC and is given by
where f1, f2, and f3 are given by

where Pa is a measure of degree of sensitization that is the precipitation of carbides at grain boundaries in an alloy, leading to IGSCC, given by Electrochemical Potentiokinetic Reactivation in C/cm2, O2 is oxygen concentration in ppm, T is temperature in °C, γ is water conductivity in μs/cm, and σ is stress in MPa.
In the above equations, Ci are constants whose values depend on the type of material. Values for these constants are given in Table 1.

caption.p: Numerical values of constants Ci used for predicting the initiation and propagation of SCC.

sec.p: The growth of very small cracks that have just initiated cannot be treated from a fracture mechanics standpoint. Therefore, an initiation velocity v1 (in/y), is assigned to newly initiated cracks, and given by
where J is normally distributed and G is a constant.
Fracture mechanics-based crack growth velocity, v2 (in/y), is given in Harris and Dedhia15 by

where K is stress intensity factor, C12, C13 and C15 are constants and C14 is normally distributed. For AISI 304 austenitic stainless steel,15J has a mean value of 2.551 and a standard deviation of 0.4269, G = 1.3447, C12 = 0.8192, C13 = 0.03621, and C15 = 1.7935; mean value of C14 = −3.1671 and its standard deviation value is 0.7260.

In their work, Priya et al.16 concluded that equations used in PRAISE to calculate the stress intensity factors in order to simulate crack propagation need modification. In our modified PRAISE (M-PRAISE) this modification has been accomplished using well-accepted expressions given in the ASM Handbook17 by equations (8) to (13). The expression for the stress intensity factor for a part-through crack in a hollow cylinder is given by

where

The values of Fa are calculated for length and depth directions separately using the tables given in the ASM Handbook.17 Since these factors are applicable for values of a/b less than 1.0, the expression for the stress intensity factor for part-through cracks in a finite plate is used when a/b becomes greater than1.0. This expression is given by

When the crack grows to become a through-wall crack, the expression for stress intensity factor used is

sec.title: Multiple cracks and their coalescence
sec.p: ‘Initiation and growth of cracks’ describes the procedures for estimating the statistical distribution of time to initiation of a stress corrosion crack. Since the bulk of the data used is for laboratory specimens, the information is applicable to laboratory-sized pieces of material, say about 2 in (50.8 mm) long.

Consequently, a given weld in a reactor pipe is considered to be composed of 2-in segments of sufficient number to add up to the length of the weld. The initiation time for each segment is assumed to be independent, and the stress within each segment is assumed to be constant.15 Only inside surface cracks are considered, because stress corrosion cracks must be exposed to the environment inside the pipe in order to initiate. Circumferential welds are divided by M-PRAISE into multiple segments 2 in in length. Each segment has only one corrosion critical location, where a crack can initiate. The multiple cracks that may be present can coalesce as they grow. Many commonly accepted recommendations are available for the safety assessment of interacting surface cracks such as BS 7910,18 R6/4,19 and Section XI of the ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code.20 However, these codes can result in either conservative or non-conservative re-characterization criteria. Recently Leek et al.21–23conducted experiments on fatigue crack growth of interacting surface cracks under mode I load, presented five different assessment methods on interacting surface cracks, and examined the coalescence of coplanar surface cracks. More information on the effect of multiple-site damage are detailed in Shi and Mahadevan24 and Pitt and Jones.25 In this study the linkage of two cracks takes place if spacing between them is less than the sum of their depths.20 After coalescence of two cracks, the dimensions of modified crack are given by
where l1 and l2 are lengths of two cracks under consideration, a1 and a2 are crack depths and d is the distance between them.

Cracks in neighboring segments may link to form larger cracks. The entire weld is assumed to be inspected at the time of each scheduled inspection. If a crack is detected in the weld, the weld is repaired, and the entire weld regains its integrity.

sec.title: Residual stresses
sec.p: Residual stresses influence both crack initiation and propagation. The damage parameter Dσ is a function of the stress, which consists of both the applied (service-induced pressure and thermal) and residual stresses. The crack-tip stress-intensity factor is given by
where Kap and Kres are the stress-intensity factors attributable to the applied stress and residual stresses, respectively.

The calculations reported here are concerned with the SCC behavior of small pipes (OD < 254 mm). Harris and Dedhia15 indicated that the plots of the cumulative distributions of the stresses on the inside surface of small pipes are normally distributed. The same assumption is assumed in this work. The through-thickness distributions of stress are assumed to be linear variations between local values sampled for the inner and outer surfaces. In the numerical examples, the mean value of residual stress at the inner surface was 168 MPa with a standard deviation of 100 MPa. The independently sampled stress at the outside surface was 168 MPa with a standard deviation of 98 MPa.

sec.title: Failure criteria
sec.p: The part-through initial stress corrosion cracks considered can grow and become unstable part-through cracks or stable or unstable through-wall cracks. The stability of the part-through or through-wall crack is checked by comparing net-section stress σnet with the flow stress σf of the material. The net-section stress criterion is applicable to very tough material, and the failure is owing to the insufficient remaining area to support the applied loads (i.e. net-section stress owing to applied loads becomes greater than the flow stress of the material, σnet >σf). For leakage failure, the criterion was that of a crack depth equal to the pipe-wall thickness.

where
σ
LC
is the load-controlled component of stress (stress owing to dead weight and operating pressure),
A
p
the area of cross-section of pipe, and
A
cr
is the area of crack given by
where Ri is the internal radius of pipe and h is the pipe wall thickness.

A defect that grows to become a stable through-wall crack is considered to have potential for leak. It is assumed that if the leak is detectable, i.e. sufficiently large, it can lead to failure of the pipe. In order to determine if a leak is detectable, it is necessary to estimate the leak rate, which in turn requires an estimate of the crack opening area. The opening area is estimated by considering the crack to be rectangular in shape in plan with a length 2b and width (crack opening displacement) of
δ
, where

where
υ
is the Poisson’s ratio, E the modulus of elasticity of pipe material, and
σ
is the applied stress. The leak rate is estimated using the expression

where
δ
the total crack opening displacement (mils), h the pipe wall thickness (in), 2b the through-wall crack length (in), and Q is the leak rate (gal/min).

If the total leak rate through all the through-wall cracks, if any, in the pipe considered, is greater than the detectable leak, the pipe is considered to have failed. In the present study, a leak rate of 0.1 gal/min is considered as the detectable leak rate, which is the regulatory requirement for a leak detection system for an unidentified leak according to NUREG-1061.16

sec.title: Inspection model
sec.p: Non-destructive examination (NDE) techniques do not detect all cracks, but can be thought of as detecting cracks with a probability that depends on crack size. The reason for expressing the ability to detect a defect by a probability measures is that the performance of inspections is dependent on many factors besides defect size, such as defect orientation, environmental conditions, inspector performance, and the inherent signal noise of the NDE equipment. The probability of detection (POD) is the mean rate of success when integrating the inspection performance over these uncertain factors. In the literature, the POD has been used to define the capability of specific NDE techniques and inspection teams.26–29 In this article, alternative inspection strategies for IGSCC were evaluated based on a set of POD curves for the ultrasonic examination of welds in 304 stainless steel piping.

sec.title: POD curves
sec.p: Pre-service and ISI by NDE techniques can be modeled. These enter into the analysis through the probability of detecting a defect during the inspection as a function of its sizes. If a crack is detected, it is assumed to be repaired, with the repaired joint being perfect. The POD on successive examinations are assumed to be independent. That is, the fact that the crack was missed on an earlier inspection does not influence the probability of detecting it on the next inspection.
In Khaleel and Simonen30 the inspection detecting probability is expressed as

where PND is the probability of non-detection, A is the area of the crack, A* is the area of crack for 50% PND, ε is the smallest possible PND for very large cracks, and ν is the ‘slope’ of the PND curve. Three POD curves, as indicated in Table 2, were selected.

caption.p: POD curve parameters for three performance levels.

tr.td: (*) h is the wall thickness of the pipe.

sec.title: Factor of improvement
sec.p: The factor of improvement (FI) is the relative increase in piping reliability owing to a given inspection strategy as compared with the strategy of performing no inspection. The FI is based on the cumulative leak probability that occurs over the 40-year design life of the plant, and is defined as the ratio

sec.title: Calibration of model
sec.p: The calibration of the PRAISE model in Harris et al.31 was redone by Khaleel et al.32,33 The calculations predicted substantial levels of material damage from loading and unloading events that used a model that applied strain-to-failure data from constant extension rate tests. A review of the damage model concluded that these predictions were extremely conservative and were inconsistent with more recent insights into SCC mechanisms. In the revised calculations, the loading/unloading events were decreased from once per year to once per 40 years, which essentially removed the contribution of these events to the calculated failure probabilities. In our case, the adjusted residual stress level used to limit the disagreement between predicted and observed leak probabilities was set at 75% (f = 0.75) of their original values. Figure 3 compares the cumulative leak probabilities given by the original M-PRAISE, Harris31 and results obtained by Khaleel et al.32,33 The resulting predictions had a much more rational basis and were in very good agreement with operational data for time periods beyond six years. The less satisfactory level of agreement for time periods less than six years can be attributed in a large measure to lack of observed failure events for the early periods of plant operation.

caption.p: Field observations of leak probabilities compared with PRAISE and M-PRAISE results for various values of the residual stress adjustment factors and plant cycles.

sec.title: Characterization of remedial residual stresses
sec.p: As-welded residual stresses often have a detrimental effect on the initiation and growth of stress corrosion cracks in sensitized weldments of BWR piping. Earlier versions of PRAISE contain default statistical distributions of residual stresses. It has been suggested that the residual stresses could be altered to become favorable, thereby improving the reliability of BWR piping. Two procedures have been proposed, induction-heating stress improvement (IHSI) and mechanical stress improvement process (MSIP). The IHSI process is suggested as one of the counter measures for IGSCC. The process results in axial residual stresses that are compressive on the inside diameter (ID) and, thus, are favorable for impeding stress corrosion crack initiation and growth. The resulting residual stresses are also axisymmetric and self-equilibrating through the thickness. Harris and Dedhia15 and Failure Analysis Associates34 provide experimental and analytical post-IHSI residual stress distributions through the wall, only the axial stresses are of interest here. These references contain results for small, intermediate, and large lines. When the stresses are linearly varying through the wall, axisymmetric and self-equilibrating, the stresses at the ID and outside diameter (OD) are related to one another by the expression
where Ri is the inside radius of the pipe and h the wall thickness of the pipe.

It appears that the post-IHSI residual stresses can be adequately described as axisymmetric with a linear through-wall gradient. For a given pipe size and thickness, such a spatial distribution can be characterized by a single number, such as the value of the stress at the ID. The results indicate that the statistical distribution of the ID residual stress is normally distributed and no consistent variation of the mean and standard deviation with pipe size.

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p: The parametric calculations concentrated on welds in 304 stainless steel piping and on the cumulative leak probabilities over a 40-year time frame of plant operation. Consideration of remedial actions for IGSCC was limited to ISIs and ISHI process. In this section the calculations were focused on leak probabilities because M-PRAISE calculates probabilities of leaks more accurately and economically than probabilities of double-ended pipe breaks. The computer program M-PRAISE has been developed on a procedure presented in Figure 4, for computing failure probabilities using the net-section stress as failure criteria and detectable leak rate.

caption.p: Evaluation of leak probabilities based on net-section stress and detectable leak rate with the M-PRAISE procedures.

sec.p: Other PFM codes for piping have been developed to calculate failure probabilities for piping. The Structural Reliability and Risk Assessment (SRRA) code35 developed by Westinghouse follows much the same approach as the PRAISE code. SCC is treated by postulating a very small initial crack, and growing the crack according to user-specified parameters for a crack growth equation. The SRRA code includes an important sampling procedure that gives reduced computation times compared with the Monte Carlo approaches used by PRAISE. The European NURBIM36 has looked at a number of codes including PRAISE as part of an international benchmarking study. Included were a Swedish code NURBIT,37 the PRODIGAL code from the UK,38 a code developed in Germany by GRS,39 a Swedish code ProSACC,40 and another code (STRUEL) from the UK.41 In any case, the predictions of all such codes are limited in large measure by the quality of the values that can be established for the input parameters, as well as the validation with service experience.

In Figure 4 the values of f1 and f3 are computed using the N values of Pa and σ generated using the MCS. Using the values of f1, f2, and f3, N values of are obtained. This represents N pipes with different Dσ, which take into account the variation in microstructural properties of the material and the operating conditions. In order to take into account the variations in the time to initiation of stress corrosion cracks, the number of samples considered is 10N. For each sample, the number of possible initiation sites in the pipe (n) considering the weld length is divided into 50.8 mm long segments along the circumference of the pipe and the values of tI are generated using the MCS. The procedures of generating crack initiation time and propagation velocities for 10N realizations of pipes are shown in Figure 4. In every time step, each one of the cracks is checked for initiation, depth, and length values of initial crack, assigned to the initiated cracks, and crack growth velocities are calculated. For all the initiated cracks in the 10N samples generated, crack propagation velocities are calculated based on initiation and fracture mechanics considerations as is appropriate. After each time step, the failure criterion, in ‘Failure criteria’ is checked. Failure probability Pf is calculated as
where Nf is the number of failure cases and NT is the total number of simulations.

Table 3 summarizes the matrix of calculations along with the input parameters for the calculations. Base-case (no ISI) M-PRAISE runs were first. These calculations assumed realistic ranges for the various input variables that govern the initiation and growth of IGSCC cracks. The following variables were addressed: O2 content, temperature, coolant conductivity, applied stress, and frequency of heat-up and cool-down. The resulting calculations therefore covered the relevant range of the Dσ parameter used to present the results in a generalized manner. This initial set of M-PRAISE runs assumed no ISI and gave calculated 40-year cumulative leak probabilities ranging from 1.0E-01 to 1.0.

caption.p: Input values for parametric calculation including the effects of ISI.

tr.td: Randomized M-PRAISE input values for small lines with adjustment of: f = 0.75
Three (3) POD curves as per Table 2
Frequency of inspection(y), (time of initial ISI/frequency)

fn.p: ID: inside diameter; SD: standard deviation; POD: probability of detection; ISI: in-service inspection.

sec.p: The second phase of the calculations included simulations of ISI for a range of POD curves and inspection frequencies as indicated in Table 3. These calculations addressed only a selected subset of the base-case calculations, but were sufficient to cover the full range of the Dσ parameter. Ratios of leak probabilities from the inspection simulation runs and the corresponding base-case runs gave values for FI. The establishment of these improvement factors for alternative inspection strategies was the primary objective of the calculations.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: A large volume of numerical data was produced by completion of parametric calculations for IGSCC of piping as described by Table 3 and Table 4. This section presents a collection of plots that show trends for pipe-leak probabilities and for the effectiveness of various ISI strategies and IHSI process in leak probabilities.

caption.p: Input values of SCC parameters and pipe loading including the effects of ISI.

tr.td: Randomized M-PRAISE input values for small lines with adjustment of: f = 0.75, Stress at ID: Mean = 168, SD = 100
Three (3) POD curves as per Table 2
Frequency of inspection (y), (time of initial ISI/frequency)

fn.p: SCC: stress corrosion cracking; SD: standard deviation; ID: inside diameter; POD: probability of detection.

sec.title: Predicted leak probability versus Dσ
sec.p: The reliability for a large number of welds and fittings in a piping system can be estimated quickly if the results of detailed MCSs are provided in a structured parametric format. Dσ values for various degrees of sensitization, different levels of applied stress, and a conductivity equal to 0.2 µS/cm, different steady state temperature and different O2 content are presented in Figure 5. The parametric calculations, as presented below, consisted of many M-PRAISE runs that covered a range of leak probabilities from 0.1 to 1. It was believed that Dσ could serve as a suitable parameter to summarize results for calculated failure probabilities of stainless steel piping. Results presented in Figure 6 show a good correlation between 40-year cumulative leak probabilities and Dσ this parameter does provide a useful basis to generalize results for piping-leak probabilities.

caption.p: Dσ Values for various degrees of sensitization, different levels of applied stress, a conductivity equal to 0.2 µS/cm: (a) a steady state temperature equal to 288 °C, for O2 content equal to 8 ppm; (b) a steady state temperature equal to 288 °C, for O2 content equal to 0.2 ppm; (c) a steady state temperature equal to 288 °C, for O2 content equal to 2 ppm; (d) a steady state temperature equal to 140 °C, for O2 content equal to 0.2 ppm.
Cumulative leak probability over 40 years as a function of the stress-corrosion damage parameter Dσ.

sec.title: Leak probability as a function of time
sec.p: For a given value of Dσ, Table 4 is used to evaluate the failure probability as a function of time. In addition to probability of crack initiation, the probability of a leak, is evaluated. Figure 7 provides a plot of these results. Figure 8 provides an example of M-PRAISE information on the number of cracks that are initiated at the start of the time increment during that trial (first number of cracks), and the number of cracks that initiated within the time increment (total initiated cracks by initiation and coalescence). Such results are printed out for each evaluation time.

caption.p: Cumulative failure probability as functions of time.
ISI: in-service inspection.
Crack initiation information from M-PRAISE.

sec.p: The effect of the arrival time of the first inspection on the leak probability is shown in Figure 9 for three different arrival times for an inspection every 10 years thereafter. From time zero to the earliest of the various arrival times, the probabilities of failure for each POD curve are identical. After the first inspection, the probabilities of failure diverge as a consequence of detecting and eliminating defects. Figure 9 shows that the cumulative leak probability for a first arrival at 10 years is lower than that for the same strategy with an arrival time at 20 years. This trend supports the selection of a strategy that includes a high-quality inspection early in life. The results of Figure 9 show that such inspections can detect a significant number of the unusually large flaws that can result in pipe failure very early in the life span of the plant.

caption.p: The effect of arrival time of first ISI on the leak probability of failure.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.

sec.p: Figure 10 shows the predicted leak probability over a 40-year plant life for the “good” NDE inspection using four inspection schedules. It can be seen that, when compared with the case of no inspection, the reliability of the pipe is not improved significantly by the “good” NDE inspection because the introduction of the initiation time for cracks into the piping reliability model would tend to give more pessimistic predictions of the benefits of inspection and that residual stresses may cause the crack growth process to slow down or arrest as the crack depth increases, which would increase the POD. However, both “very good” and “advanced” NDE inspections provide an improvement and reduce leak probabilities, as shown in Figures 11 and 12, respectively. A “very good” NDE inspection can cat the leak probabilities from 0.277 for no ISI to 0.124 (schedule ISI (1/1)) at the end of plant life. With an “advanced” NDE inspection, the leak probabilities become 0.141 (schedule ISI (10/10)), 0.082 (schedule ISI (4/4)), 0.054 (schedule ISI (2/2)), and 0.037 (schedule ISI (1/1)) at the end of plant life. Better inspection procedures (“very good” versus “good” and “advanced” versus “very good”) appear to offer a cost-effective option for enhancing piping performance. In Figure 13 the results indicate that use of a better procedure can be more effective than a ten-fold increase in the number of inspections with the continued use of an inferior procedure.

caption.p: Cumulative leak probability based on “good” NDE inspection and four inspection schedules.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.
Cumulative leak probability based on “very good” NDE inspection and four inspection schedules.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.
Cumulative leak probability based on “advanced” NDE inspection and four inspection schedules.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.
Impact of inspection procedures.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.

sec.title: Effect of ISI
sec.p: The individual data points for improvement factors exhibited some data scatter, which was addressed by using a regression analysis to establish best fit curves (second-order polynomial) in terms of improvement factors versus the logarithm (base 10) of Dσ and the corresponding leak probabilities. For clarity, the plots below show only the best fit curves rather than the individual data points. Figures 14 to 18 show predicted improvements in reliability over a 40-year design life for small pipe size that results from ISIs performed over the 40-year operating period and describes inspections performed at a Y-year interval and with the first inspection at the Xth year using the notation X/Y. Three different levels of NDE performance are addressed. In Figures 14 to 16, the inspection method was held constant, and the inspection intervals ranged from 1 to 10 years. Figures 17 and 18 show the same set of results, but with the curves rearranged to maintain a common inspection interval for each plot, with the individual curves corresponding to different POD curves.

caption.p: Improvement factors versus Dσ for “good” POD curve with various inspection intervals.
FI: improvement factor; ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.
Improvement factors versus Dσ for “very good” POD curve with various inspection intervals.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.
Improvement factors versus Dσ for “advanced” POD curve with various inspection intervals.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.
Improvement factors versus Dσ for one-year ISI interval with various POD curves.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.
Improvement factors versus Dσ for 10-year ISI interval with various POD curves.
ISI: in-service inspection; POD: probability of detection.

sec.p: It is seen that POD curves with the better detection probabilities always increase the factor improvement, no matter what inspection interval is used. However, the results show that even the “advanced” POD curve requires frequent inspection to achieve meaningful reductions in failure probabilities. The inspections with the “good” and “very good” POD curves (Figures 14 and 15) give more meaningful enhancement in piping reliability. The greatest benefits are predicted for the “advanced” NDE technology and procedures, for which an order-of-magnitude improvement on the leak probability can be achieved for an inspection frequency of once per year. This improvement factor of 10 is still significantly less than the theoretical limit of 200 (1/ε = 1/0.005 = 200) for the “advanced” POD curve. The lower benefits of ISI for IGSCC compared with the benefits for fatigue crack growth can be explained in terms of long incubation periods for stress-corrosion cracking followed by a period of rapid crack growth.

sec.title: Effect of changing residual stresses during mid-life
sec.p: If wall thickness of the pipe is changed in mid-life, then the stresses owing to pressure are recalculated. If the thickness is changed, the residual stress distributions are renormalized such that the stress is the same as before at any given fractional depth through the wall. If a change in residual stress is desired in mid-life, it can only be changed to axisymmetric self-equilibrating through the wall. Figure 19 presents results for the cases where residual stresses were changed by IHSI treatment at 20 years. The distribution of these residual stresses is defined by specifying the mean and standard deviation of the stresses on the ID of the pipe. The recommended post-IHSI stress distribution based on the data analyzed in this article (mean = −308 MPa, standard deviation = 78 MPa) has a large effect on reducing the leak probabilities following the IHSI treatment.

caption.p: Effect of reducing residual stress at midlife with IHSI process.
IHSI: induction-heating stress improvement.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A probabilistic stress-corrosion cracking model was applied to assess the effect of various inspection scenarios on leak probabilities. It was believed that Dσ could serve as a suitable parameter to summarize results for calculated failure probabilities of stainless steel piping. These results show a good correlation between 40-year cumulative leak probabilities and this parameter does provide a useful basis to generalize results for piping-leak probabilities. This article has also discussed POD curves and the benefits of ISI in the framework of reductions in the leak probabilities for nuclear piping systems subjected to IGSCC based on Dσ. The results for typical NDE performance levels indicate that low inspection frequencies (one inspection every 10 years) can provide only modest reductions in failure probabilities. More frequent inspections appear to be even more effective. However an “advanced” NDE reliability can achieve a factor of 10 improvements in preventing IGSCC leaks at typical operating conditions even when inspections occur approximately every 10 years; this can be increased to a factor even greater than 10 if the inspection interval is decreased sufficiently. Finally the recommended post-IHSI residual stress has a large effect on reducing the leak probabilities and the lower benefits of ISI for IGSCC can be explained in terms of long incubation periods for stress-corrosion cracking followed by a period of rapid crack growth.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: a crack depth
A0–6 coefficients computed from the table given in ASM Handbook
Acr area of crack
Ap area of cross-section of pipe
b one-half of crack length
C1–C9 material dependent constants
C12,C13,C15 material dependent constants
C14 material dependent random variable
d spacing between two cracks
D σ damage parameter
E modulus of elasticity
f1 sensitization term
f2 environmental term
f3 loading term
F material dependent random variable
G material dependent constant
h pipe wall thickness
J material dependent random variable
K stress intensity factor
Ka stress intensity factor in the depth direction of crack
Kap stress intensity factor for applied stress
Kb stress intensity factor in the length direction of crack
Kres stress intensity factor for residual stress
l, l1, l2 crack length
n number of possible initiation sites in the pipe
N number of simulations
NT total number of simulations
Nf number of failure cases
O2 oxygen concentration
Pa degree of sensitization
Pf probability of failure
Q leak rate
Ri internal radius of pipe
tI time to initiation of stress corrosion cracking
T temperature
v1 initiation crack growth velocity
v2 fracture mechanics based crack growth velocity
W width of the plate
γ water conductivity

δ
crack opening displacement
ε smallest possible PND for very large cracks

σ
